title: James â€“ Adult Spastic Cerebral Palsy with Lower Limb Spasticity
clinical_history: James is a 38-year-old accountant with a known diagnosis of spastic diplegic cerebral palsy since early childhood. He ambulates independently with the use of bilateral forearm crutches. Over the past 3 months, James has noticed increasing difficulty with transfers and prolonged walking. He reports progressive tightness and spasms, particularly in both hamstrings and adductors, with associated pain and increased fatigue by midday. His gait is characterized by scissoring, crouched posture, and toe-walking. While he is still able to independently manage self-care and work responsibilities, his walking distance and speed have declined. He is concerned about worsening function and increasing fallsâ€”experiencing three non-injurious falls in the past month.

nprs.affected_area: bilateral calves (secondary muscle pain due to compensatory overuse)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged walking (beyond 10-15 minutes), ascending and descending stairs, cold weather (increases muscle stiffness), fatigue (worsens tone and spasms), stress, quick positional changes.
easing_factors: Rest, gentle stretching, warm compresses, use of standing frame, use of antispasmodic medication in the evening, hydrotherapy.
past_history: Premature birth at 30 weeks, spent 2 months in NICU due to respiratory distress. Multiple orthopedic interventions in childhood for Achilles tendon lengthening and adductor release at ages 7 and 12. No significant surgeries in adulthood. Attends physiotherapy intermittently.
medical_history: Asthma (well-controlled), mild hypertension diagnosed 2 years ago. No cardiac or recent respiratory issues.
medications: Baclofen 10mg twice daily (antispasmodic), PRN ibuprofen 400mg (<3x/week, mostly post-physiotherapy), Salbutamol inhaler as needed.
personal_history: Single, lives independently in an accessible apartment. Works full-time as an accountant. Drives an adapted vehicle. Enjoys reading and online gaming. Reports higher stress recently due to upcoming work deadlines. Family lives out-of-town but visits monthly.
imaging: Most recent hip and knee X-rays (6 months ago) show mild degenerative changes in bilateral hips and knees, no acute findings.
